There are no visible islands in the vicinity of algiers...--[[User:Burgas00|Burgas00]] 17:38, 1 June 2006 (UTC) This is really quite a complex question. The name of the city varied in the old times in Arabic: some wrote it "jazayer" others wrote it "zayer" (obviously this is vocal transliterations I'm writing with latin characters). "jazayer" means "the islands" in Arabic. "zayer" means absolutely nothing in Arabic. Anyways... as the city grew powerful in the middle ages it also became the name of the country Algeria (Algeria is called "el jazayer" today in Arabic) like Tunis to the East gave its name to Tunisia and Marakech to the West gave its name to Morocco. The thing is that in Algeria there is an Arab and a Berber culture. Today those who want to promote Arabic identity of Algeria claim that "el jazayer" means "islands" and is a proper Arabic word (just like el jazira, the TV station means "the island" or "the peninsula". singular). Those who want to promote Berber identity claim that in the historical books it was written more like "zayer" originally. So the 2 viewpoints are these: - "zayer", which means absolutely nothing if taken as a noun in Arabic comes from the fact that the man who rebuilt the city was called Ziri. And he was a Berber prince. "Zayer" therefore would mean "Ziri's city". - To make matters worse, those who support Arabic identity and the theory of "the islands" actually have a case too. There used to be 4 small islands in front of the old city which was much smaller than the modern Algiers. The old city was located in the left side of the bay on the satellite picture and it is today the Casbah district of modern Algiers. The islands got linked to the land however over centuries. The last island ceased to exist as an island in the 16th century. It was the one which the Spanish had built a massive fort with an artillery based there, from which they bombed the city continuously in order to obtain it's surrender in the 16th century. When the residents of Algiers captured the fort from the Spanish, they destroyed the fort and used its blocks to link this last island to the city. I think that was around in 1520. Over time therefore, there is no more islands left. So the origin of the name of the city is a matter of discussion between Algerians themselves. The fact that the city gave it's name to the country makes the discussion a national one. And the fact that the government which suppressed Berber culture for a decades took sides with the Arabic theory of "jazayer" (also written djazair in latin characters) has pushed many defendants of Berber culture into the arms of the theory of "zayer" or the Berber prince [[Buluggin ibn Ziri]]'s city. What exactely is the truth? I personally don't know but I think that its both at the same time. Voilà for this quite Mediteranean dispute over a name :) Cordially, a resident of Algiers [[User:82.101.153.210|82.101.153.210]] 06:34, 22 September 2006 (UTC) The Arabic version has the longer documented history, as [[Abu Abdullah al-Bakri]] writing in the 11th century calls it "the islands" belonging some tribe I forget who. And I've also seen it somewhere that the Phoenician name ''Ikosim'' meant ''seagull islands''. Anyway, is it not odd that neither Arab nor Berber explanation of the name is given in the article, but another one? [[User:Mathglot|Mathglot]] ([[User talk:Mathglot|talk]]) 03:25, 29 January 2024 (UTC) == Demonym == The term ''demonym'' is never used in this article, and I think I understand why: the situation is rather confusing. In French, the term ''algerien'' originally meant someone from Algiers, and it retained that meaning until around 1892, when ''algerois'' took over that meaning, and is still used today for inhabitants of the city. In English, there is the ambiguous ''Algerian'', and in older sources, ''Algerine''. For sources and more details on this, see [[Talk:Algeria#Terminology of Algeria and Algiers]]. We have ''Tangierian'' in English for residents of [[Tangiers]], but the analogous situation for Algiers yields the ambiguous ''Algerian'', and I suspect that's why it's not covered. The province is divided into districts, which are further divided into actual city propers which cover metropolitan Algiers. There is no Algiers City, in that respect so this sentence in the beginning paragraph: "According to the 1998 census, the population of the city proper was 1,519,570..." jh ted local government for the urban area, or is there not really an Algiers city in terms of local governance? --[[User:Criticalthinker|Criticalthinker]] ([[User talk:Criticalthinker|talk]]) 12:52, 14 February 2011 (UTC) :Come on; someone has to know. --[[User:Criticalthinker|Criticalthinker]] ([[User talk:Criticalthinker|talk]]) 03:05, 8 September 2011 (UTC) == province and city == the article Algiers referrences both a coty and a province, I suggest they are seperated --[[User:The Brain|The Brain]] 11:47, 6 September 2005 (UTC) Why is Algiers called the islands? There are no visible islands in the vicinity of algiers...--[[User:Burgas00|Burgas00]] 17:38, 1 June 2006 (UTC) This is really quite a complex question. The name of the city varied in the old times in Arabic: some wrote it "jazayer" others wrote it "zayer" (obviously this is vocal transliterations I'm writing with latin characters). "jazayer" means "the islands" in Arabic. "zayer" means absolutely nothing in Arabic. Anyways... as the city grew powerful in the middle ages it also became the name of the country Algeria (Algeria is called "el jazayer" today in Arabic) like Tunis to the East gave its name to Tunisia and Marakech to the West gave its name to Morocco. The thing is that in Algeria there is an Arab and a Berber culture. Today those who want to promote Arabic identity of Algeria claim that "el jazayer" means "islands" and is a proper Arabic word (just like el jazira, the TV station means "the island" or "the peninsula". singular). Those who want to promote Berber identity claim that in the historical books it was written more like "zayer" originally. So the 2 viewpoints are these: - "zayer", which means absolutely nothing if taken as a noun in Arabic comes from the fact that the man who rebuilt the city was called Ziri. And he was a Berber prince. "Zayer" therefore would mean "Ziri's city". - To make matters worse, those who support Arabic identity and the theory of "the islands" actually have a case too. There used to be 4 small islands in front of the old city which was much smaller than the modern Algiers. The old city was located in the left side of the bay on the satellite picture and it is today the Casbah district of modern Algiers. The islands got linked to the land however over centuries. The last island ceased to exist as an island in the 16th century. It was the one which the Spanish had built a massive fort with an artillery based there, from which they bombed the city continuously in order to obtain it's surrender in the 16th century. When the residents of Algiers captured the fort from the Spanish, they destroyed the fort and used its blocks to link this last island to the city. I think that was around in 1520. Over time therefore, there is no more islands left. So the origin of the name of the city is a matter of discussion between Algerians themselves. The fact that the city gave it's name to the country makes the discussion a national one. And the fact that the government which suppressed Berber culture for a decades took sides with the Arabic theory of "jazayer" (also written djazair in latin characters) has pushed many defendants of Berber culture into the arms of the theory of "zayer" or the Berber prince [[Buluggin ibn Ziri]]'s city. What exactely is the truth? I personally don't know but I think that its both at the same time. Voilà for this quite Mediteranean dispute over a name :) Cordially, a resident of Algiers [[User:82.101.153.210|82.101.153.210]] 06:34, 22 September 2006 (UTC) The Arabic version has the longer documented history, as [[Abu Abdullah al-Bakri]] writing in the 11th century calls it "the islands" belonging some tribe I forget who. And I've also seen it somewhere that the Phoenician name ''Ikosim'' meant ''seagull islands''. == Some contradictions ==

There is a long tradition of presenting bias, nationalistic sympathies and misinterpretations, ahistorical notes and additions by later authors,  and outright nonsense when referring to this battle. This Wikipedia article complies well with this tradition. Most of the references are by authors who never visited the area and have very distorted information about the battle’s whereabouts.   Let me address (some of) the issues point by point.

The goal of the Serbian army. The article has it’s “make a surprise attack on the Ottomans in their capital city, Edirne, while Murad I was in Asia Minor.” This is at odds with the size of the army. Surprise attacks are carried on with small mobile armies. Moreover, the fact that the Ottomans themselves surprised the Serbian army suggests that they had prior knowledge of the army’s movements, which rules out the ‘’surprise’’ factor. If the intention was to capture Edrine, as the location of the battle highly suggests, this is again at odds with the size of the army and the date of the events. You do not need 50000-70000 men for a siege of a city. Late September is probably the strategically worst time to begin sieges, as crops are already harvested, the supplies are presumed to be already collected, and there are no issues with drought and heat. Simultaneously you bind much manpower, which is critically needed during field activities in a very active agricultural season.   If the intention was to get rid of the Ottomans from the Balkan peninsula then it is more logical to wait until Murad returns to perform a decisive blow against the whole Ottoman power, rather than look for temporary goals, which are likely to be avenged later on. It seems that the most likely goal was a preemptive blow, and some sources claim that Murad was planning a war either with Serbia or with Bulgaria at the time. 

The route of the Serbian army. Contrary to what the map in the article (original unsourced work with purely speculative authenticity)  and John Fine claims, the domains of King Vukašin Mrnjavčević and his brother Despot Jovan Uglješa and the territories controlled by the Ottomans were not immediate neighbors. They were divided by the Rhodope mountains and the latter were never Serbian territories. Large armies are unlikely to pass through mountainous areas, especially if there was no rationale to do so.   This leaves essentially two routes that the Serbian army may have taken. The northern one, which is more likely, follows the ancient Via Militaris. It passes through Bulgarian territory and leaves open the problem of the Bulgarian involvement in the campaign. It is known that after their victory at Chernomen, the Turks immediately turned on Bulgaria. This is strange if the Bulgarians stayed uninvolved and the main Ottoman forces stayed in Asia Minor, but at least supports the ’’northern route’’. The southern one follows the ancient Via Egnatia. This route requires passing through Byzantine territories, and at the time the relations between Byzantium and Serbia were hostile because of the Serbian schism.  Also, then it would have been strategically far more clever to pass the Marica river at a convenient downstream location.

The date of the battle. I do not know of a reliable contemporary source fixing the date on 26 September. It is notable that exactly 25 years later, on the same date, the massacre of the POWs at Nicopolis happened. There are more common traits with the Nicopolis battle (both battles happened near a river, in both cases the Turks appeared unexpectedly, both battles involved large Christian armies which were annihilated, and in both cases, the Christian army had a long passage before the events) which leaves open the problem of a possible bias. 
     
The exact location of the battle. I do not know of a reliable contemporary source fixing the location at Chernomen. I am not aware of any archeological studies confirming the location. Turkish sources place the battle at Sirp Sindigi, on the left bank of Marica. The left bank seems far more probable for a series of reasons. Most notably, the Serbian army tried to flee through the river. Had they been on the right bank near Chernomen, it is not logical for them to look for refuge on the right (Turkish) bank through a wide river such as Marica. Unless you are pushed to or encircled (the Turks lacked the manpower to do so), you do not tend to jump at night into an unknown wide and possibly deep river: https://www.google.pl/maps/@41.7730265,26.1921474,3a,75y,163.25h,84.63t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sYKXTdqXWrZnzqnQxSRpOiA!2e0!7i16384!8i8192
 The existence of a ford must have been known to the Serbs, who probably used it the previous day. 

The sequence of events. According to http://astropixels.com/ephemeris/phasescat/phases1301.html
On 26 September 1371 it was almost full moon. Unless it was raining, it would have been a very bright night with very good visibility. The terrain is very flat. See yourself: https://www.google.pl/maps/@41.7072647,26.2424501,3a,75y,27.41h,86.41t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1svGi5Ev4iej9nYvuJoHUsTA!2e0!6shttps:%2F%2Fstreetviewpixels-pa.googleapis.com%2Fv1%2Fthumbnail%3Fpanoid%3DvGi5Ev4iej9nYvuJoHUsTA%26cb_client%3Dmaps_sv.tactile.gps%26w%3D203%26h%3D100%26yaw%3D203.55655%26pitch%3D0%26thumbfov%3D100!7i13312!8i6656
 Although I do not know anything about the forestation of the area, it seems that in such circumstances it is unlikely that significant forces would approach unnoticed.  It is unlikely that the Serbians did not set guards or reconnaissance, as the distance to Edrine is just 20-30 kilometers, so they were literally almost on the spot, well inside the Enemy territory. In my opinion, the only two possible explanations are an exhaustive passage through the river (there was no bridge at the location in the middle ages) earlier in the day, which supports the ‘’left bank’’ conjecture above, or a betrayal inside the Serbian camp.  The latter is probable, as the Turkish sources claim that the Serbians killed each other in the mess. 

,,After the battle, the Maritsa ran scarlet with blood’’. This does not happen as a result of drowning, stampede or killings that are not located immediately by the river bank. The only two possible explanations of the phenomenon (if it is not just literary fiction) are that either the Serbians fought each other for the limited places in boats or rafts, or there were massive executions of POWs at the river bank. Both suggest a possible bias with the battle of Nicopolis.  <!-- Template:Unsigned IP --><small class="autosigned">— Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/31.182.220.23|31.182.220.23]] ([[User talk:31.182.220.23#top|talk]]) 02:22, 8 May 2022 (UTC)</small> <!--Autosigned by SineBot-->

: '''Result''': Rockado with change of flag ie. the soldiers abandon their leaders who drown in the waters of Maritsa and join the new janissary corps as warriors. Otherwise, there is no way the bill will come out!

== Source reliability audit ==

I am conducting a source reliability audit for this article in accordance with [[WP:RS]], [[WP:HISTRS]], and [[WP:UNDUE]]. The goal is to replace outdated, non-academic, or self-published materials with modern, peer-reviewed, or university-press scholarship.
The following works do not meet modern reliability standards for historical scholarship or fail verification requirements (age, publisher type, or author credentials):
*Vladislav Bosković, King Vukašin and the Disastrous Battle of Marica (GRIN Verlag, 2009) – self-published print-on-demand thesis, fails [[WP:SPS]].
*The New Encyclopaedia Britannica: Micropaedia (1993) – tertiary reference, not a scholarly or specialist source per [[WP:TERTIARY]].
*Ion Grumeza, The Roots of Balkanization (University Press of America, 2010) – popular narrative history, non-peer-reviewed; author not a historian by training. See [[WP:QUESTIONABLE]]
*Julius Emil DeVos, Fifteen Hundred Years of Europe (1924) – dated general work with no scholarly apparatus. See [[WP:AGEMATTERS]]
*Otto Kaemmel, Spamer’s Illustrierte Weltgeschichte (1902) – 19th-century popular history; obsolete historiography. See [[WP:AGEMATTERS]]
*Theodor Veiter, Volkstum zwischen Moldau, Etsch und Donau (1971) – incomplete bibliographic data; unclear authorship; unverifiable. Fails [[WP:VERIFY]]
*Temperley (1917) and Hertzberg (1877) – early secondary works superseded by modern scholarship; usable only for historiography, not factual claims. See [[WP:AGEMATTERS]]
I propose grounding the article primarily in the following current, high-reliability academic sources, many of them authored by recognised authorities on Byzantine, Ottoman, and Balkan studies:
*[[John Van Antwerp Fine Jr.|John V. A. Fine Jr.]], The Late Medieval Balkans (1994, University of Michigan Press) – comprehensive modern survey of the region, standard in university curricula.
*[[Sima Ćirković|Sima M. Ćirković]], The Serbs (2008, Blackwell) – authoritative monograph by a leading Serbian medievalist.
*[[Donald Nicol|Donald M. Nicol]], The Last Centuries of Byzantium (2nd ed., 1993, Cambridge UP) – foundational work on the late Byzantine world.
*[[Alexander Mikaberidze]], Conflict and Conquest in the Islamic World (2011, ABC-CLIO) – peer-reviewed reference synthesizing Islamic military history.
*[[Stephen Turnbull (historian)|Stephen Turnbull]], The Ottoman Empire 1326–1699 (Bloomsbury Academic, 2003) – specialist military historian
*[[Halil İnalcık]], The Ottoman Empire: The Classical Age 1300–1600, trans. Norman Itzkowitz & Colin Imber (Praeger, 1978) – seminal work by the foremost twentieth-century Ottoman historian.
*Abdülkadir Özcan, "Çirmen Muharebesi" in Türkiye Diyanet Vakfı İslam Ansiklopedisi (2003) – standard Turkish academic encyclopaedia entry by a leading Ottomanist. 
*Aleksandar Šopov, The Historical Visions of the Battle of the Maritsa / Meriç (MA thesis, Sabancı University, İstanbul, Türkiye  2007) – scholarly study analyzing historiography and memory of the battle.
*Stephen W. Reinert, "Maritsa, Battle of," Encyclopaedia of Islam, 3rd ed. (Brill, 2021) – most recent peer-reviewed synthesis by a leading Byzantine and Balkan historian.

All replaced citations will be fully crosschecked for verifiability, any objections or further academic recommendations are welcome. -[[User:Aeengath|Aeengath]] ([[User talk:Aeengath|talk]]) 10:44, 15 October 2025 (UTC)

:I don't feel qualified to give an Official Third Opinion™, but I attempted to do some research upon the question:
:{{hr}} 
:* I believe @[[User:Aeengath|Aeengath]] correctly interprets the guideline as saying that we ought be most concerned with what (English-speaking) authors use when writing ''about'' the time-period in question, rather than what authors who were writing ''during'' the time-period in question used ''at the time'' (although this latter criterion ''would also,'' of course, be relevant—certainly would demonstrate a long, and likely wide... er, so to speak... acceptance of a term—but, ''in the case that'' we are lacking any such texts, I believe that the aforementioned interpretation is what is meant).
:* Conducting some unscientific surveys & spot-checks of relevant (historical/academic) texts, I find that '''Scutari''' or '''Skutari''' are the most common in general.  '''Skadar''' seems slightly more common than its Albanian rival in general historical (meaning ''about''—mostly Byzantine, medieval, & Renaissance—history) books or papers; and '''Shkodër''' seems slightly more common than its Slavic nemesis in the more recent-ish books or papers about (very roughly) the specific time-period in question.  (So... uh... well, that may not have been very enlightening, heh.)
:* Very often, I see something like ''"[...] Scutari (Shkodër) [...]".''  This may or may not be relevant for Wiki purposes, but I thought I'd note that ''"name (parenthetical variant)"'' does have something of a pedigree.
:* Looking at [https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=Skutari%2BScutari%2CSkadar%2CShkod%C3%ABr%2CShkodra&year_start=1922&year_end=2022&corpus=en Google Ngrams], it seems to affirm the general Anglish preference for '''Scutari;''' next-most-common, at least recently, appears to be ''Shkodra'' (...which I forgot to check for when doing the Unscientific Survey™; whoops); ''Skadar'' and ''Shkodër'' are neck-&-neck, and it's hard to glimpse much daylight between 'em.
:* ''Scutari'' makes the others fade into oblivion, if one adjusts the temporal window to be a bit wider; removing it, we get [https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=Skadar%2CShkod%C3%ABr%2CShkodra&year_start=1822&year_end=2022&corpus=en this], wherein we can see that ''Shkodra'' is indeed a recent phenomenon, and—historically—'''Skadar''' appears to have the edge over ''Shkodër''...
:* ...but Ngrams doesn't limit itself to sources ''about'' history, so it is hard to know how much this popular preference for ''Scutari'' or ''Skadar'' is likely to be reflected therein.  There's probably a ''non-zero'' correlation; but maybe not enough to outweigh the Proper Historians' preferences, in the case that they be different...?
:{{hr}}
:'''TL;DR:'''  ...Iunno, y'all; 'stough to say.  But given all of the above, I might swing for '''''"Scutari''''' ''(modern-day'' '''''Shkodër)"'''''—just if it were me.
:{{hr}} 
:Cheers, amigos.  Hope this helps, somehow—and my apologies in the very likely event that it doesn't, heh.

::::Hey [[User:Himaldrmann|Himaldrmann]], I really appreciate you putting in so much time and effort to what, from the outside, would seem like such a small and insignificant debate. The only reason why I feel that this is so important is because it will set the precedent for all other related articles that discuss Shkodër in the Middle Ages, so whatever is decided here will form the basis for how we go about naming things in those articles as well. I suppose my response should be dictated towards your remaining uncertainties:
::::* {{tquote|Does the existence of a W.A.H.N. in English in other contexts trump the "use local name" clause triggered by the apparent lack of a W.A.H.N. for this particular context?...}} I think the existence of a W.A.H.N. for the 14th century would be heavily-tied to whatever the W.A.H.N. is for the "neighbouring" centuries as well. Considering many articles talk about the late 14th/early 15th century in tandem, for example, we can't switch from different forms for two sentences that happened with the same figures/polities but only a few years apart. IMO, it should remain consistent.
::::* {{tquote|Does "well, it was known as Skadar to the 14th-century Principality of Zeta" have any standing, according to the guidelines...}} This is the core of Aeengath’s argument, but as you also noticed, the guidelines don’t say “use whatever the local ruling power called it at the time” - they say “use the widely accepted historical English name.” Fine deliberately chose 'Skadar' based on his methodology, but that doesn’t automatically make it the English historical name. The fact that Cambridge, Madgearu, Norris, Kiel, and others use 'Shkodër' for the same century shows that “Skadar” is not widely accepted in English, but rather one author’s convention. What I have consistently said is that I’m fine with ‘Scutari (modern Shkodër)’ if consensus swings that way as a compromise, as long as the footnote is attached listing all common historical variants without giving prominence to one over the other, because that’s not what sources do. We probably don’t even need ‘(modern Shkodër)’ if we hyperlink Scutari and add the footnote immediately after listing all variants.
::::::::::::As for sources, I’ve already listed several that use Shkodër for the exact same time frame, and I’m sure I could find more — Kiel (1990), Norris (1993), Swire (1937), Madgearu (2008), Cambridge History (2009). Aeengath’s response that “those don’t describe Maritsa” misses the point, and ironically, neither do all of the sources they just listed. Britannica and Roberts are broad histories that don’t even talk about Maritsa when mentioning Shkodër, Truhart is a reference catalogue, and Shopov is an MA thesis (widely-cited though) that uses Skadar/Shkodër interchangeably. The fact remains: there is no single “widely accepted historical English name” across the scholarship. Some say Skadar, some Shkodër, some Scutari.
::::::::::::That is exactly why WP:UEGN exists - to avoid chopping up articles line by line based on whatever spelling each individual author prefers. If we followed Aeengath’s logic, an article might use three different spellings for the same city within the same few decades depending on the source cited, which would be chaotic. It is also strange to have different articles use different spelling for the same timeframe, which is another reason why WP:UEGN exists. Policy resolves this by saying: if there is no widely accepted historical English name, use the local one. That means Shkodër, but I’ve already agreed to compromise on ‘Scutari’ with a footnote, just because it might be more prevalent for the Middle Ages.
::::::::::::For clarity and consistency across articles, the best policy-compliant solution is IMO: main text = Shkodër, with a footnote listing the other forms (Skadar, Scutari, Shkodra, whatever else). That way we stay aligned with guidelines, we respect all the sources, and we give readers the full picture without turning the article into a patchwork of competing spellings. But, failing that, I would agree to ‘Scutari’ with a footnote doing the same. 
::::::::::::Finally, [[User:Donner60|Donner60]], I don’t think the American Revolutionary War and Civil War examples you cite are actually comparable here. Those cases involve places whose names changed later under the same line of polities (e.g. towns incorporated, merged, or renamed) and editors noting both the old and new forms. That’s not what we’re dealing with in Shkodër. Shkodër was not some later invention or renaming; it was already the native/local form in use during the 14th century, alongside the other variants. The situation is different because we’re not choosing between a former name that disappeared and a modern name that replaced it - we’re choosing between several co-existing exonyms, none of which is the “widely accepted historical English name”. That is exactly the scenario WP:UEGN was written for, and it points us clearly toward the local name. 
::::::::::::I think an RfC would be a bit too much, the reason why it’s dragged out is because, realistically, the form used here should be used on corresponding articles. So, in a way, it’s deciding those articles too. If we really want to make a special exception where only one article on Wiki uses ‘Skadar’ for the Middle Ages, sure I guess, but I would hope such usage wouldn’t spread to similar articles, because this whole debate will have to be repeated again and again... == Some contradictions ==

There is a long tradition of presenting bias, nationalistic sympathies and misinterpretations, ahistorical notes and additions by later authors,  and outright nonsense when referring to this battle. This Wikipedia article complies well with this tradition. Most of the references are by authors who never visited the area and have very distorted information about the battle’s whereabouts.   Let me address (some of) the issues point by point.

The goal of the Serbian army. The article has it’s “make a surprise attack on the Ottomans in their capital city, Edirne, while Murad I was in Asia Minor.” This is at odds with the size of the army. Surprise attacks are carried on with small mobile armies. Moreover, the fact that the Ottomans themselves surprised the Serbian army suggests that they had prior knowledge of the army’s movements, which rules out the ‘’surprise’’ factor. If the intention was to capture Edrine, as the location of the battle highly suggests, this is again at odds with the size of the army and the date of the events. You do not need 50000-70000 men for a siege of a city. Late September is probably the strategically worst time to begin sieges, as crops are already harvested, the supplies are presumed to be already collected, and there are no issues with drought and heat. Simultaneously you bind much manpower, which is critically needed during field activities in a very active agricultural season.   If the intention was to get rid of the Ottomans from the Balkan peninsula then it is more logical to wait until Murad returns to perform a decisive blow against the whole Ottoman power, rather than look for temporary goals, which are likely to be avenged later on. It seems that the most likely goal was a preemptive blow, and some sources claim that Murad was planning a war either with Serbia or with Bulgaria at the time. 

The route of the Serbian army. Contrary to what the map in the article (original unsourced work with purely speculative authenticity)  and John Fine claims, the domains of King Vukašin Mrnjavčević and his brother Despot Jovan Uglješa and the territories controlled by the Ottomans were not immediate neighbors. They were divided by the Rhodope mountains and the latter were never Serbian territories. Large armies are unlikely to pass through mountainous areas, especially if there was no rationale to do so.   This leaves essentially two routes that the Serbian army may have taken. The northern one, which is more likely, follows the ancient Via Militaris. It passes through Bulgarian territory and leaves open the problem of the Bulgarian involvement in the campaign. It is known that after their victory at Chernomen, the Turks immediately turned on Bulgaria. This is strange if the Bulgarians stayed uninvolved and the main Ottoman forces stayed in Asia Minor, but at least supports the ’’northern route’’. The southern one follows the ancient Via Egnatia. This route requires passing through Byzantine territories, and at the time the relations between Byzantium and Serbia were hostile because of the Serbian schism.  Also, then it would have been strategically far more clever to pass the Marica river at a convenient downstream location.

The date of the battle. I do not know of a reliable contemporary source fixing the date on 26 September. It is notable that exactly 25 years later, on the same date, the massacre of the POWs at Nicopolis happened. There are more common traits with the Nicopolis battle (both battles happened near a river, in both cases the Turks appeared unexpectedly, both battles involved large Christian armies which were annihilated, and in both cases, the Christian army had a long passage before the events) which leaves open the problem of a possible bias. 
     
The exact location of the battle. I do not know of a reliable contemporary source fixing the location at Chernomen. I am not aware of any archeological studies confirming the location. Turkish sources place the battle at Sirp Sindigi, on the left bank of Marica. The left bank seems far more probable for a series of reasons. Most notably, the Serbian army tried to flee through the river. Had they been on the right bank near Chernomen, it is not logical for them to look for refuge on the right (Turkish) bank through a wide river such as Marica. Unless you are pushed to or encircled (the Turks lacked the manpower to do so), you do not tend to jump at night into an unknown wide and possibly deep river: https://www.google.pl/maps/@41.7730265,26.1921474,3a,75y,163.25h,84.63t/data=!3m6!1e1!3m4!1sYKXTdqXWrZnzqnQxSRpOiA!2e0!7i16384!8i8192
 The existence of a ford must have been known to the Serbs, who probably used it the previous day. 

The sequence of events. According to http://astropixels.com/ephemeris/phasescat/phases1301.html
On 26 September 1371 it was almost full moon. Unless it was raining, it would have been a very bright night with very good visibility. The terrain is very flat. See yourself: https://www.google.pl/maps/@41.7072647,26.2424501,3a,75y,27.41h,86.41t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1svGi5Ev4iej9nYvuJoHUsTA!2e0!6shttps:%2F%2Fstreetviewpixels-pa.googleapis.com%2Fv1%2Fthumbnail%3Fpanoid%3DvGi5Ev4iej9nYvuJoHUsTA%26cb_client%3Dmaps_sv.tactile.gps%26w%3D203%26h%3D100%26yaw%3D203.55655%26pitch%3D0%26thumbfov%3D100!7i13312!8i6656
 Although I do not know anything about the forestation of the area, it seems that in such circumstances it is unlikely that significant forces would approach unnoticed.  It is unlikely that the Serbians did not set guards or reconnaissance, as the distance to Edrine is just 20-30 kilometers, so they were literally almost on the spot, well inside the Enemy territory. In my opinion, the only two possible explanations are an exhaustive passage through the river (there was no bridge at the location in the middle ages) earlier in the day, which supports the ‘’left bank’’ conjecture above, or a betrayal inside the Serbian camp.  The latter is probable, as the Turkish sources claim that the Serbians killed each other in the mess. 

,,After the battle, the Maritsa ran scarlet with blood’’. This does not happen as a result of drowning, stampede or killings that are not located immediately by the river bank. The only two possible explanations of the phenomenon (if it is not just literary fiction) are that either the Serbians fought each other for the limited places in boats or rafts, or there were massive executions of POWs at the river bank. Both suggest a possible bias with the battle of Nicopolis.  <!-- Template:Unsigned IP --><small class="autosigned">— Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/31.182.220.23|31.182.220.23]] ([[User talk:31.182.220.23#top|talk]]) 02:22, 8 May 2022 (UTC)</small> <!--Autosigned by SineBot-->

== Source reliability audit ==

I am conducting a source reliability audit for this article in accordance with [[WP:RS]], [[WP:HISTRS]], and [[WP:UNDUE]]. The goal is to replace outdated, non-academic, or self-published materials with modern, peer-reviewed, or university-press scholarship.
The following works do not meet modern reliability standards for historical scholarship or fail verification requirements (age, publisher type, or author credentials):
*Vladislav Bosković, King Vukašin and the Disastrous Battle of Marica (GRIN Verlag, 2009) – self-published print-on-demand thesis, fails [[WP:SPS]].
*The New Encyclopaedia Britannica: Micropaedia (1993) – tertiary reference, not a scholarly or specialist source per [[WP:TERTIARY]].
*Ion Grumeza, The Roots of Balkanization (University Press of America, 2010) – popular narrative history, non-peer-reviewed; author not a historian by training. See [[WP:QUESTIONABLE]]
*Julius Emil DeVos, Fifteen Hundred Years of Europe (1924) – dated general work with no scholarly apparatus. See [[WP:AGEMATTERS]]
*Otto Kaemmel, Spamer’s Illustrierte Weltgeschichte (1902) – 19th-century popular history; obsolete historiography. See [[WP:AGEMATTERS]]
*Theodor Veiter, Volkstum zwischen Moldau, Etsch und Donau (1971) – incomplete bibliographic data; unclear authorship; unverifiable. Fails [[WP:VERIFY]]
*Temperley (1917) and Hertzberg (1877) – early secondary works superseded by modern scholarship; usable only for historiography, not factual claims. See [[WP:AGEMATTERS]]
I propose grounding the article primarily in the following current, high-reliability academic sources, many of them authored by recognised authorities on Byzantine, Ottoman, and Balkan studies:
*[[John Van Antwerp Fine Jr.|John V. A. Fine Jr.]], The Late Medieval Balkans (1994, University of Michigan Press) – comprehensive modern survey of the region, standard in university curricula.
*[[Sima Ćirković|Sima M. Ćirković]], The Serbs (2008, Blackwell) – authoritative monograph by a leading Serbian medievalist.
*[[Donald Nicol|Donald M. Nicol]], The Last Centuries of Byzantium (2nd ed., 1993, Cambridge UP) – foundational work on the late Byzantine world.
*[[Alexander Mikaberidze]], Conflict and Conquest in the Islamic World (2011, ABC-CLIO) – peer-reviewed reference synthesizing Islamic military history.
*[[Stephen Turnbull (historian)|Stephen Turnbull]], The Ottoman Empire 1326–1699 (Bloomsbury Academic, 2003) – specialist military historian
*[[Halil İnalcık]], The Ottoman Empire: The Classical Age 1300–1600, trans. Norman Itzkowitz & Colin Imber (Praeger, 1978) – seminal work by the foremost twentieth-century Ottoman historian.
*Abdülkadir Özcan, "Çirmen Muharebesi" in Türkiye Diyanet Vakfı İslam Ansiklopedisi (2003) – standard Turkish academic encyclopaedia entry by a leading Ottomanist. 
*Aleksandar Šopov, The Historical Visions of the Battle of the Maritsa / Meriç (MA thesis, Sabancı University, İstanbul, Türkiye  2007) – scholarly study analyzing historiography and memory of the battle.
*Stephen W. Reinert, "Maritsa, Battle of," Encyclopaedia of Islam, 3rd ed. (Brill, 2021) – most recent peer-reviewed synthesis by a leading Byzantine and Balkan historian.

All replaced citations will be fully crosschecked for verifiability, any objections or further academic recommendations are welcome. -[[User:Aeengath|Aeengath]] ([[User talk:Aeengath|talk]]) 10:44, 15 October 2025 (UTC)

:* Conducting some unscientific surveys & spot-checks of relevant (historical/academic) texts, I find that '''Scutari''' or '''Skutari''' are the most common in general.  '''Skadar''' seems slightly more common than its Albanian rival in general historical (meaning ''about''—mostly Byzantine, medieval, & Renaissance—history) books or papers; and '''Shkodër''' seems slightly more common than its Slavic nemesis in the more recent-ish books or papers about (very roughly) the specific time-period in question.  (So... uh... well, that may not have been very enlightening, heh.)
:* Very often, I see something like ''"[...] Scutari (Shkodër) [...]".''  This may or may not be relevant for Wiki purposes, but I thought I'd note that ''"name (parenthetical variant)"'' does have something of a pedigree.

::::Hey [[User:Himaldrmann|Himaldrmann]], I really appreciate you putting in so much time and effort to what, from the outside, would seem like such a small and insignificant debate. The only reason why I feel that this is so important is because it will set the precedent for all other related articles that discuss Shkodër in the Middle Ages, so whatever is decided here will form the basis for how we go about naming things in those articles as well. I suppose my response should be dictated towards your remaining uncertainties:
::::* {{tquote|Does the existence of a W.A.H.N. in English in other contexts trump the "use local name" clause triggered by the apparent lack of a W.A.H.N. for this particular context?...}} I think the existence of a W.A.H.N. for the 14th century would be heavily-tied to whatever the W.A.H.N. is for the "neighbouring" centuries as well. Considering many articles talk about the late 14th/early 15th century in tandem, for example, we can't switch from different forms for two sentences that happened with the same figures/polities but only a few years apart. IMO, it should remain consistent.
::::* {{tquote|Does "well, it was known as Skadar to the 14th-century Principality of Zeta" have any standing, according to the guidelines...}} This is the core of Aeengath’s argument, but as you also noticed, the guidelines don’t say “use whatever the local ruling power called it at the time” - they say “use the widely accepted historical English name.” Fine deliberately chose 'Skadar' based on his methodology, but that doesn’t automatically make it the English historical name. The fact that Cambridge, Madgearu, Norris, Kiel, and others use 'Shkodër' for the same century shows that “Skadar” is not widely accepted in English, but rather one author’s convention. The guidelines clearly don't support the use of 'Skadar', to this line of argumentation really shouldn't overtake policy in terms of importance.
::::Furthermore, the Principality of Zeta wasn’t a homogeneous South Slavic state. The ruling [[Balsha family]] is regarded by many scholars as having Albanian origins (see article). Much of the surrounding country was and remains Albanian-speaking: all of the regions neighbouring Shkodër such as [[Zadrima]], [[Pult]], [[Malësia e Madhe]], and [[Ana e Malit]] are historically attested as having a dominant Albanian-majority; even in the [[Brda]] region farther north exist several tribes commonly treated in scholarship as of Albanian origin - [[Kuči]], [[Vasojevići]], [[Bratonožići]], [[Piperi]], [[Bjelopavlići]], all of which were still Albanian-speaking during the later Middle Ages. Other coastal/montane communities under Balsha influence, e.g. [[Paštrovići]] and [[Malonšići]], had strong ethnic Albanian components as well, if not being entirely of Albanian origin. So while sources in the Maritsa context might use 'Skadar', it doesn’t follow that the Principality of Zeta itself - which controlled all of these lands at some point in time in the 14th century - “uniformly” called it that, nor that 'Skadar' is the historically accepted English form for this era. 
::::As a follow-up to your note - {{tquote|... if @Botushali were to source his contention that Shkodër was just as, or perhaps even more-so, used at the time, then that might be fairly decisive in favor of Shkodër (by this standard)}} - I think I have indicated above that Shkodër and its surrounding region consisted primarily of Albanians during this period of time; all of those articles can be checked for their sourced info, I suppose. Furthermore, from 'A Concise History of Albania' (2022) by Schmitt and Fischer, we have the following: {{tquote|Albanians encountered place-names on the Adriatic coast between 150 BC in the north (Ulcinj/Alb. Ulqin, It. Dulcigno, Shkodër/Srb. Skadar/It. Scutari, Lezhë/lt. Alessio)...}} So Albanians, who formed the majority of Shkodër and its surrounding regions in this period of time, were using 'Shkodër' since at least 150 BC, which I think satisfies your query as to whether or not Shkodër was the most commonly-used term at the time - if that's what you meant of course. Either way, I don't think that has any bearing on the guidelines, which should adjudicate the final result of this matter.
::::In summary, [[User:Donner60|Donner60]] favours 'Scutari (modern day Shkodër)', Aeengath favours 'Skadar (modern day Shkodër)', and I favour 'Shkodër', but I would not mind swapping to 'Scutari (modern day Shkodër)' if you, [[User:Himaldrmann|Himaldrmann]], were to support that over 'Shkodër', although we simply cannot justify using 'Skadar' according to the given guidelines. So I suppose, with the scores even, it's ultimately up to you. This way, we can finally reach a consensus and put this conversation to rest.
::::Whatever the case, I think a reasonable fallback would be to include a short explanatory footnote, as Donner suggested, listing all the principal historical forms of the name (Skadar, Scutari, Shkodra, etc.) alongside the modern Shkodër - or, if we swing to Scutari, then Scutari (modern day Shkodër). That way, readers are fully informed of the variants, we stay consistent with [[WP:UEGN]]/[[WP:PLACE]], and we avoid setting a confusing precedent of name-switching between different articles. ::::* ''On sources and verifiability'': I don’t think the "source count" comparison is very meaningful here, as most works using ''Shkodër'' don’t describe the 1371 campaign or the Principality of Zeta:
::::''Kiel (1990)'' – Ottoman architecture, 1385–1912.
::::''Norris (1993)'' – religion and society, not the Maritsa campaign.
::::''Swire (1937)'' – modern political history, mentions 1366 only in passing.
::::''Somel (2011)'' – Ottoman–Venetian War, 1460–1479.
::::''Madgearu (2008)'' – notes the Balšić residence at Shkodër in 1362, but not the 1371 mobilisation described by ''Fine (1994)''.
::::By contrast, ''Fine (1994)'' and ''Shopov (2006)''¹ are the only English language works that actually describe that campaign and both use ''Skadar''. ''Britannica (2002)'' describes {{tq|Zeta (...) with its capital at Skadar}} and ''Roberts'' (''2007, Realm of the Black Mountain, p. 8'' [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QKslEQAAQBAJ&newbks=1&newbks_redir=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=Realm+of+the+Black+Mountain&hl=en&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=then%20known%20as%20Skadar%20(later%20Scutari%2C%20then%20Shkodra)&f=false]) confirm the city was {{tq|then known as Skadar (later Scutari, then Shkodra)}}, clearly showing the chronological progression.
::::In short, none of these ''Shkodër'' sources describe the specific military movement in question: the Zetan army assembling in ''Skadar'' before the Battle of Maritsa.
::::¹Per [[WP:THESIS]] ''Shopov (2006)'', a 149-page MA thesis supervised by Ottoman historian Yusuf Hakan Erdem, remains the only full-length English study of the Battle of Maritsa. Its findings on Skadar/Shkodër align fully with ''Fine (1994)''.
::::* ''On accuracy and policy'': since the cited source (''Fine 1994, p. 379'') literally use ''Skadar'', substituting another name would detach the text from its citation and contradict [[WP:V]] and [[WP:TSI]]. ''Scutari'' is not the name used in the cited source and only appears a few decades later during the Venetian period, hence its use in ''Tony Jaques (2007)''. Using it here would risk a mild anachronism and synthesis under [[WP:OR]].
::::* ''On historical consistency'': as ''Truhart'' (''1984, p. 3322''[https://archive.org/details/regentsofnations0001truh/page/3322/mode/2up?q=%22skadar+zeta%22]) records ''Skadar/Zeta'' was the seat of rule under the Nemanjić dynasty from the late twelfth century until 1371. When ''Fine'' writes that {{tq|Vukašin and his son Marko in the summer of 1371 marched west to Zeta (...) they were all together in Skadar preparing for action}} that phrasing matches both the history and the way the period is described in English scholarship.
::::For that reason, I believe the policy verifiable and historically precise form is '''Skadar (modern Shkodër)''', keeping the sentence aligned with its source and avoiding anachronism. If consensus lands on '''Scutari (modern Shkodër)''' for broader consistency as proposed by [[User:Donner60|Donner60]], that’s fine too, as long as we add a short footnote clarifying that ''Scutari'' only became current later under Venetian rule.

::::::::OK, so we all agree on a footnote listing the historical variants - that seems like the most constructive compromise and ensures readers get the full picture.
::::::::That said, I do want to address [[User:Aeengath|Aeengath]]’s repeated reframing that sources discussing the Battle of Maritsa use 'Skadar'. The Battle of Maritsa was a conflict between the Serbs and the Ottomans in what is today Greece, and Shkodër is mentioned only in passing. A source passingly mentioning 'Skadar' in reference to Maritsa hardly makes it the “historical English name” for Shkodër in the 14th century. By that logic, if one event uses a certain spelling and another event a few years later uses a different spelling, we would constantly switch names mid-article depending on the author. Imagine how inconsistent and unreadable articles would look if we actually followed that standard. That’s exactly why [[WP:UEGN]] exists - to avoid that kind of arbitrary inconsistency. One term should be used for ''all'' articles.
::::::::Also, I think we should be cautious about leaning so heavily on Encyclopedia Britannica. Per [[WP:BRITANNICA]], Britannica is a [[WP:TERTIARY]] source. It’s fine to consult, but it doesn’t override broader policy or the weight of usage in modern scholarship. And while Aeengath cites Britannica to support 'Skadar', the article they cited doesn’t explicitly connect their usage of 'Skadar' to Maritsa either - it’s just being highlighted because it aligns with Aeengath's preferred spelling, despite going against the same line of argumentation they keep using.
::::::::So with the footnote agreed on, we now need to finally decide the main form to use. [[User:Himaldrmann|Himaldrmann]] has indicated support for 'Shkodër' (which makes two of us). Aeengath worries that 'Scutari' is anachronistic, but would accept it in order to avoid the Albanian spelling. 'Skadar' is simply not acceptable under the guidelines, as we've established. My preference remains 'Shkodër', especially since, as Aeengath pointed out, 'Scutari' is more Venetian and came into use after the Balshas handed the town over to the Republic of Venice in 1396. But, I'm sure sources exist that use 'Scutari' in a 14th-century context. Due to the complexity of the matter, the easiest and least-confusing way to go about this IMO would be to just use '[[Shkodër]]', which is the Wiki article's current title, and be done with it. [[WP:UEGN]] clearly states that if no W.A.H.N. exists, we should use the modern local name. If there's no more objections, I'd be happy to insert the footnote on the end of 'Shkodër'. :::::::::* Fine (1994, p. 379) clearly doesn’t mention Skadar "in passing", since Fine uses the form ''Skadar'' throughout ''The Late Medieval Balkans'' (over forty times) and more importantly explicitly places Vukašin’s army in ''Skadar'' as the staging point before the 1371 campaign.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=LvVbRrH1QBgC&pg=PA379&dq=#v=onepage&q=Skadar&f=false] 
:::::::::That’s the action described in the article’s sentence, so following the source wording is required under [[WP:V]] and [[WP:TSI]], which both emphasise maintaining text–source integrity: keeping the article’s wording aligned with what the cited source actually says.
:::::::::* ''On the chronology'': I’m relying on four English-language references that align with Fine:
:::::::::** ''Shopov (2006)'' — a 149-page MA thesis supervised by Ottoman historian Yusuf Hakan Erdem and still the only full-length English study of the battle. It uses ''Skadar/Shkodër'' on first mention "{{Talk quote inline|in the early summer of 1371 Vukašin with his son Marko was in the vicinity of Skadar/Shkodër preparing to attack the župan Nikola Altomanović}}" and then ''Skadar'' for the mobilisation “{{Talk quote inline|Vukašin to withdraw from the position in Skadar and join his brother’s army in the military offensive against the Ottoman}}”. [https://research.sabanciuniv.edu/id/eprint/8505/]
:::::::::** ''Truhart (1984)'' — ''Regents of Nations'', a major scholarly reference work that lists ''Skadar/Zeta'' as the seat of rule under the Nemanjić dynasty through 1371. [https://archive.org/details/regentsofnations0001truh/page/3322/mode/2up?q=%22skadar+zeta%22]
:::::::::** Encyclopaedia Britannica (2002) — describes "{{Talk quote inline|chiefdom of Zeta (…) with its capital at Skadar}}". [https://books.google.co.uk/books?redir_esc=y&id=aoVUAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=skadar]
:::::::::** ''Roberts (2007)'' — ''Realm of the Black Mountain (Hurst)'', by Balkan historian and former British diplomat Elizabeth Roberts, confirms the sequence of the city {{Talk quote inline|then known as Skadar (later Scutari, then Shkodra)}} (p. 8). [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QKslEQAAQBAJ&newbks=1&newbks_redir=0&printsec=frontcover&dq=Realm+of+the+Black+Mountain&hl=en&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=then%20known%20as%20Skadar%20(later%20Scutari%2C%20then%20Shkodra)&f=false]
:::::::::Together these show that Skadar is the historically accurate form for this 1371 event; Scutari emerges later under Venetian rule, and Shkodër is the modern form.
:::::::::For that reason, the verifiable and policy-clean version of the Fine-sourced sentence is "Skadar (modern Shkodër)". As I said earlier, I’m fully open to consensus, and if "Scutari (modern Shkodër)" is chosen for consistency, I’m ok with that provided, as [[User:Donner60|Donner60]] suggested, we include a short note outlining the chronology of names (Skadar → Scutari → Shkodër) in the spirit of maintaining accuracy and clarity. My only goal here is to keep the article both verifiable and historically consistent with its cited source.
:::::::::Using Shkodër alone would detach the line from its cited source and imply the city already had that name in 1371, which no English-language source supports.
:::::::::Finally, just to clarify for the record: my concern about Scutari is '''historical''', not linguistic, it’s simply a later Venetian form, which is why I support the proposal to mention it alongside the other historical variants. I have no objection to using the Albanian name ''Shkodër'' if it fits chronologically or if English reliable sources use it in describing the 1371 campaign. The key is to keep the name consistent with the context described in the article per ''Fine (1994)'' and supported by multiple English-language sources.

::::::::::::I have never said that ‘Skadar’ shouldn’t be mentioned at all. What I have consistently said is that I’m fine with ‘Scutari (modern Shkodër)’ if consensus swings that way as a compromise, as long as the footnote is attached listing all common historical variants without giving prominence to one over the other, because that’s not what sources do. ::::::::::::As for sources, I’ve already listed several that use Shkodër for the exact same time frame, and I’m sure I could find more — Kiel (1990), Norris (1993), Swire (1937), Madgearu (2008), Cambridge History (2009). Aeengath’s response that “those don’t describe Maritsa” misses the point, and ironically, neither do all of the sources they just listed. Britannica and Roberts are broad histories that don’t even talk about Maritsa when mentioning Shkodër, Truhart is a reference catalogue, and Shopov is an MA thesis (widely-cited though) that uses Skadar/Shkodër interchangeably. The fact remains: there is no single “widely accepted historical English name” across the scholarship. Some say Skadar, some Shkodër, some Scutari.
::::::::::::That is exactly why WP:UEGN exists - to avoid chopping up articles line by line based on whatever spelling each individual author prefers. If we followed Aeengath’s logic, an article might use three different spellings for the same city within the same few decades depending on the source cited, which would be chaotic. It is also strange to have different articles use different spelling for the same timeframe, which is another reason why WP:UEGN exists. Policy resolves this by saying: if there is no widely accepted historical English name, use the local one. That means Shkodër, but I’ve already agreed to compromise on ‘Scutari’ with a footnote, just because it might be more prevalent for the Middle Ages.
::::::::::::For clarity and consistency across articles, the best policy-compliant solution is IMO: main text = Shkodër, with a footnote listing the other forms (Skadar, Scutari, Shkodra, whatever else). That way we stay aligned with guidelines, we respect all the sources, and we give readers the full picture without turning the article into a patchwork of competing spellings. But, failing that, I would agree to ‘Scutari’ with a footnote doing the same. 
::::::::::::Finally, [[User:Donner60|Donner60]], I don’t think the American Revolutionary War and Civil War examples you cite are actually comparable here. Those cases involve places whose names changed later under the same line of polities (e.g. towns incorporated, merged, or renamed) and editors noting both the old and new forms. That’s not what we’re dealing with in Shkodër. Shkodër was not some later invention or renaming; it was already the native/local form in use during the 14th century, alongside the other variants. The situation is different because we’re not choosing between a former name that disappeared and a modern name that replaced it - we’re choosing between several co-existing exonyms, none of which is the “widely accepted historical English name”. That is exactly the scenario WP:UEGN was written for, and it points us clearly toward the local name.

A W.A.H.N. isn’t determined by whether a single historian opts for ‘Skadar’ in one event narrative; rather, it’s determined by broader scholarly usage across the timeframe in question. 
:::::That’s why I cited Premović, Molina, Zachariadou, and others before that - not because they narrate Maritsa at great depth itself (although they do mention it), but because they show that in the same chronological window (before, during, and after 1371), the preference across wider scholarship is for Shkodër (or Scutari). Premović and Giakoumis even make a point of saying {{tquote|… between the residents of Shkodra (Skadar in Slav.) …}}, mentioning ‘Skadar’ only once as the term in ''Slavic'' (not as the historical English name), before reverting exclusively to Shkodra throughout the study. That’s an acknowledgment of a variant, not a declaration that it was the accepted name. To spin it otherwise is misleading, and your selective framing and misquoting of that sentence goes against [[WP:V]], which you insist on using inappropriately.
:::::The idea that [[WP:V]] or [[WP:PLACE]] require us to replicate whatever spelling one author happens to use for one sentence is simply not what policy dictates. What policy ''does'' dictate is that, when no single W.A.H.N. exists, use the local name. That’s Shkodër. The compromise on ‘Scutari’ with a footnote listing variants already respected that balance and could have closed this discussion some time ago.
:::::Insisting instead on elevating ‘Skadar’ based on two selective references isn’t policy-driven, it’s cherry-picking. It doesn’t outweigh the wider literature, and it certainly doesn’t override the naming guideline that applies here, as I’ve had to repeatedly state an untold number of times to the point where it’s just getting ridiculous. Also, the Petrograd/Leningrad analogy doesn’t apply. It’s a false comparison. Those were official state-imposed name changes with hard start and end dates that are reflected in sources on their respective eras. Shkodër was never “renamed” to ‘Skadar’ in that sense, because these are parallel exonyms that coexisted in the literature, and the usage of ‘Shkodër’ predates ‘Skadar’ by more than roughly five centuries as cited above to Schmitt and Fischer…

The first record only states that Nobunaga employed him as a porter and gave him a few stipends after Alessandro Valignano gave Yasuke to Nobunaga. In addition to this, the second one (diary) simply records physical characteristics of Yasuke. The third one depicts how Mitsuhide Akechi （[[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Akechi_Mitsuhide|明智光秀]]）decided to treat Yasuke immediately after Nobunaga died. First of all, the crucial point is that when a lord Nobunaga died, if Yasuke was a samurai and one of liegemen close to Nobunaga, he should be killed at the same time or he should commit seppuku. But it's written in the Jesuit Annual Report of Japan that, Akechi said "This black guy is a beast (an animal, not a human), he doesn't know anything, and he's not Japanese, so I won't kill him" and let Yasuke go, saying, "Leave him with an Indian priest" Second important point is that Yasuke was not given a surname, which a "real" samurai would have had. Moreover, if he had achieved some military exploits as a samurai, there would have been some kind of records left (like other Sengoku warlords), but none of such remains. For these reasons, it is a commonly held opinion among Japanese that Yasuke was not a samurai. In other words, Yasuke did not do anything worthy of records, and that's why most Japanese people have not cared about his existence much. Japanese historican Dr. Yuichi Goza concluded that Yasuke was "in fact Nobunaga’s porter and a kind of entertainer". ([[https://www.sankei.com/article/20240805-2RDCMCMKMNFYFOGXMRGPCIT2NI/ 弥助問題「本人は芸人のような立場」「日本人の不満は当然」　歴史学者・呉座氏に聞く]]) Whilst the theory "Yasuke was a samurai" quickly spread overseas due to the book written by Thomas Lockley and due to the falsification of English Wikipedia's "Yasuke" entry. In the Japanese version of his book, Lockley made a small disclaimer, saying that most parts of his book are mere conjecture without any historical fact-checking, in other words, it's a fiction. But in the English version, he treated those parts of his own fiction as if they were facts,writing them in assertive tone. Regarding Wikipedia's "Yasuke" entry, there's no description that Yasuke was a samurai in Japanese page, but in English page, it's written like "served as a samurai to the Japanese daimyō Oda Nobunaga for a period of 15 months between 1581 and 1582", which had been obviously edited by Lockely using the pseudonym Tottoritom, and it's still there (now that English page got locked (non-editable)...probably because of the flood of criticism against his fabrication?).
